author.value: Finding aid prepared by Colin Wells

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-06T15:23-0500</date>

unittitle.value: David C. Bohnett Collection of Winsor McCay Drawings

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
Winsor McCay (1867-1934) was a cartoonist, animator, and performer credited with significant influence in the development of American comic strips and motion picture animation. McCay first gained attention with two comic strips, 
                <title render="italic">Dream of the Rarebit Fiend</title>, which began publication in the 
                <title render="italic">New York Evening Telegram</title> in 1904, and 
                <title render="italic">Little Nemo in Slumberland</title>, first published in the 
                <title render="italic">New York Herald</title> in 1905. In 1911 McCay began introducing animated films into his vaudeville act, beginning with 
                <title render="italic">Little Nemo</title> and in the following year, 
                <title render="italic">How a Mosquito Operates</title>. In 1914 McCay introduced 
                <title render="italic">Gertie the Dinosaur</title>, which would become his most well known animated work. It is widely considered the preeminent animated work before the development of the Disney studio. This collection consists of two original production animation drawings of Gertie the Dinosaur from 1914.

p.value: Open to researchers. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival collections.

Published citations should take the following form:
                <lb/>
                <lb/>Identification of item, date (if known); Winsor McCay Animation Drawings; MSS 226; box number; folder number; 
                <address>
                    <addressline>Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.</addressline>
                </address>

Sources: (1) Canemaker, John. 
                <emph render="italic">Winsor McCay: His Life and His Art.</emph> New York: Harry N. Abrams, 2005.
                <lb/> (2) "David Bohnett Bio." The David Bohnett Foundation. Accessed February 26, 2009. http://www.bohnettfoundation.org/personnel/view/1
This collection consists of a single series containing two original production ink drawings on rice paper of Gertie the Dinosaur, with certificates of authenticity from The Animation Celection.

dsc.value:
Series I: Animation Drawings 2 folders 1914 Scope and Content

This series consists of two original production ink drawings on rice paper of Gertie the Dinosaur, with certificates of authenticity from The Animation Celection.

 Gertie the Dinosaur and Mammoth 1 1 1914 General note

Depicts a line drawing of Gertie the Dinosaur looking at a mammoth walking in a rocky landscape. Drawing is numbered 188. Ink drawing on rice paper, 6.5 x 8.5 inches.

 Gertie the Dinosaur and Winsor McCay 1 2 1914 General note

Depicts a line drawing of Gertie the Dinosaur followed by a man walking in a rocky landscape. Drawing is numbered 267. Ink drawing on rice paper, 6.5 x 8.375 inches.
